Doing a good job of team announcements is hard enough. When you have difficult news to share, it gets harder. We can quickly do a lot of damage to trust and morale if we announce bad news badly.
 Even if you don’t have bad news to share, tricky team announcements need to happen all the time. This is just as true for companies that are doing well as for those that are struggling. If you’re subscribed to  my email course, or you’re following the advice in my posts on  deployment or  focus, then you’ll have had some difficult discussions with your team which will require them to experience change. Additionally, many of us are living in the midst of or in the aftermath of lockdown after the coronavirus. Teams are changing priority and focus due to COVID-19, and are often doing so remotely. Some teams are growing. Other teams are shrinking. It’s a tough time for everyone, and great communication in team announcements is more crucial than ever.
 Here are a couple of embarrassing stories about how I’ve failed in this area in the past, along with some tips for doing it better.
  The first announcement I tried to make wasn’t a team announcement, but it’s instructive regardless.
 I was a final-year student, working on a fledgling business with three friends. We’d built an open source search service for email mailing lists and had brought it to a Linux user group. This was early 1999: nobody was indexing mailing lists at the time. As far as we knew, it was the first of its kind. We had something to share we were genuinely excited about.
 After we set up our enormous CRT monitor and desktop on a trestle table in the demo area, I nonchalantly said to the others that I’d give the announcement during the lunchtime open mike session. I was brimming with excitement and confidence, so I didn’t prepare anything beforehand. I assumed that as soon as I got up in front of everyone I would know what to say.
 The time came for me to speak. There was quite a crowd at this point: more than I’d been expecting.  Alan Cox was in the audience, no less. As soon as I heard my name called, my heart leapt into my throat, and stayed there. I slowly walked to the front, mumbled a greeting, and froze. I remember blurting out a string of “ers” and “ahs” without making any kind of sense, murmured that we had a table upstairs, and fled for my life.
 I’m not sure how much of a difference this made to our little enterprise, but it didn’t help. Not many people came to see our product that day, and it never quite got off the ground. The four of us amicably parted ways a couple of months later. The experience stuck with me and I vowed to do better the next time I had to give an important announcement.
   Fast forward a dozen years or so, and I was running a small client services company I’d founded in 2004. I was riding high on our early successes. We had a lovely team of about twelve developers, and a nice office in the centre of Winchester, UK. There was just one small problem: it was the height of the tech crunch in 2011, and our cash was running out.
 My senior team implored me to level with the team about the situation we found ourselves in. They argued that if I announce the bad news now, that way the team would have at least some idea that there might be problems in the weeks ahead. I agreed, though sadly my 32 year old self hadn’t learnt any lessons from my 20 year old self. Yet again, I didn’t prepare properly. I just assumed that all the words would come out in the right order.
 My memory is a little hazy of the actual meeting. I do remember standing in front of the team talking, but I don’t remember exactly what I said. I remember feeling quite optimistic and felt that I’d given a rallying speech. My team looked happy enough as I scanned their faces afterwards, with perhaps a trace of confusion here and there. I turned to my senior people, and their faces were livid.
  Immediately afterwards, in the cramped little meeting room at the corner of our office, I received a twenty minute castigation from my senior team for telling bare-faced lies in the previous meeting. I couldn’t believe it. I had tried to be reassuring and upbeat, to jolly everyone along. My intention was never to lie to the team. However, I had not told the whole truth. Along the way, I had missed some of the crucial facts. Without preparing properly, I’d neglected my duty as CEO and had inadvertently misled the team.
 My senior people were furious, and one of them quit soon after. When I did eventually level with the team, it caused a lot of surprise and shock, and our finances had got much worse by then. If I’d done a better job of communicating earlier, then the news would have been easier for them to stomach.
 Thinking back, that sinking realisation that I’d not told the truth despite meaning well is still one of the most depressing moments of my career. It’s down there with that sad day a few months later where we finally did run out of money and closed the company.
  If you’ve been leading teams for any length of time, you may have your own horror stories like these. Eventually we learn how to manage these tricky meetings. Here are some pointers to help.
  One of the reasons that it’s a challenge to deliver bad news is because as organisational leaders we always experience the news differently to our team. “It’s natural to feel ambivalence” when we announce bad news, according to Joshua Margolis, a professor at Harvard Business School. We’re constantly thinking about both our employees and the needs of the company at the same time: a perspective that can be lost on our people. They don’t always get to see the big picture.
 This was certainly true for my second example above. From conversations with peers, I knew we could turn the corner if only we could survive a few months. My team hadn’t had these conversations, and could only see clouds gathering. I could see the silver linings glimmering in the distance. If I’d done a better job of talking about our cash flow problems, I could have earned enough trust to help the team see what I saw.
  You cannot be over-prepared when you announce bad news, or any other news for that matter.
 These days, before any team announcement, I prepare fastidiously. My method is to write at least several hundred words just to get my thoughts in order. I then distil from these notes exactly what I want to say, choosing my words carefully to try and instil the understanding I’m after.
 Team announcements can be stressful and we can feel confused and disoriented, especially when you have to announce bad news. It’s especially hard to share bad news remotely via video call. Sometimes I find it helpful to re-read all my thoughts to ensure I remember the sense of what I’m trying to communicate just before I go in to a meeting.
 If you’re new to this, don’t trust that teams see things the way you do. Communication is difficult. As I discuss in my posts about  correcting team members and  dealing with mistakes, we must strive to ensure what we say actually goes in, is understood, and elicits change. If we fail in this, we have done more harm than good.
  Some team announcements from experienced leaders can feel very spontaneous. It seems like they’ve just thought of what they’re going to say that minute. Don’t believe it. It takes a lot of preparation before something feels spontaneous.
 Steve Jobs used to give legendary product presentations when demoing Apple’s latest products. It sometimes felt like you were chatting with a friend about the latest cool technology you discovered. In reality,  he would meticulously prepare for a month in advance, going over and over the material and refine every line and slide until it was perfect.
 It’s worth rehearsing your announcement out loud, so you can hear how it sounds. If you have trusted people who are aware of the news already, rehearse with them first before going to the team. Get them to ask you tricky questions afterwards, the tougher the better. It might feel odd doing this, but it allows you to practice giving good answers when it doesn’t matter if you fail. The more rehearsed you are, the more spontaneous your announcement will feel.
  Research by professors at Brigham Young University and the University of South Alabama shows that when sharing bad news, the absolute worst thing we can do is beat around the bush and try and make things seem better than they really are. Most people prefer directness, candour and very little buffer. This also takes practice and preparation, as it’s hard not to sugar coat things for people in order to prevent pain. Unfortunately that causes them more pain and confusion in the long run. We must not do it. I’ve found that the more natural empathy someone has, the harder they have to work at this.
 Even when sharing good news, it’s important to be direct and tell the whole truth. Most good news is qualified in some way: “customers loved the new product!” (but can’t afford to buy it) or “we make a big sale to a client!” (but they want new features immediately or they’ll cancel within three months). What you experience as good news might not always been considered good news by your team. Put yourself in their shoes, figure out how they might experience it in advance, and tell the whole truth.
  If you’ve had to reach a difficult decision, when you announce the bad news, explain the thought process you went through to get there. People are much more forgiving of bad news if they feel that they understand the rationale behind your decision making. It helps them understand why these decisions must be made, and that you’re carefully considering all the options.
 It’s ok to allow people to vent and show emotion. However, don’t enter into debate there and then in the meeting about whether your rationale was the right one. It’ll cause you to hesitate, put you on the back foot, and then the rest of the team will lose confidence. If people do bring up good points that you’ve not prepared for, thank them for their contribution and promise to pick their questions up later in a  one-to-one discussion.
  It’s important to acknowledge what’s happened, but it’s also important to focus on the future and what’s next for your team and for the organisation. People will find it easier to get over it when you announce bad news if you give them hope and aspirations for what’s next.
 It helps if these are as concrete and real as possible, but even if there seems to be no hope at all you can find a silver lining. For example, even when all hope is lost for your team, or you have to let people go, you can remind them that relationships last longer than companies, and friendships can last a lot longer than employee/employer relationships, and that this is an opportunity for new things. Try hard to find a way to lead them forward.
  Next time you have to announce bad news to your team, avoid my terrible early mistakes. Prepare extremely carefully and be as direct as possible. Explain your thought process and encourage your team forward with you into the future. That way, you’ll have a chance of preventing your team’s delivery from stalling in the wake of a botched announcement, and keep the team with you through the inevitable process of change.
